DOCUMENT.NOTES: This field is populated by the <NOTES> node of the "objects.xml" document. Simply paste/edit text between the <NOTES></NOTES> tags. Formatted text can be used here. However, do not use ", &, < or >. Instead, use """, "&", "<" and ">".

QUESTION.QuestionLead: You want to secure the access of the Cart.aspx page by using Forms-based authentication.
QUESTION.QuestionText: Where do you have to do that?

AnswerId.ResultValue: Global.asax is used to catch the events, but it is not used to configure the application. Try something else.
The page does not set its own security. Try something else.

Answer.AnswerWrong: Wrong choice, try something else.

QUESTION.QuestionLead: Now, you want to be able to let the user enter their credentials and create a non-persistent authentication cookie. The authenticated user will then be redirected to the requested page.
QUESTION.QuestionText: Where do you have to do that?

AnswerId.ResultValue: Global.asax is used to catch the events, but it is not used to enter the credentials. Try something else.
Web.config is used to configure the application, but it is not used to enter the credentials. Try something else.

Answer.AnswerWrong: Wrong choice, try something else.

QUESTION.QuestionLead: By using the ProductID parameter, cache the products page for 90 seconds to improve its performance.
QUESTION.QuestionText: Where do you have to do that?

AnswerId.ResultValue: Global.asax is used to catch the events, but it is not used to set up the cache. Try something else.
Web.config is used to configure the application, but it is not used to set up the cache. Try something else.
Machine.config is used to set up the default configuration that is used for all of the ASP.NET Web applications. Try something else.

Answer.AnswerWrong: Wrong choice, try something else.

QUESTION.QuestionLead: You want to create a price watcher public function that returns the price of any product item based on the item number. You want to let any Web developer have access to this function.
QUESTION.QuestionText: Where do you have to do that?

Answer.AnswerWrong: Wrong choice. This page does not allow you to expose a method through the Web. Try something else.

QUESTION.QuestionLead: To display the price of a product in the product page, you want to consume your XML Web service method GetPrice(intItemNumber).
QUESTION.QuestionText: Where do you have to do that?

Answer.AnswerWrong: Wrong choice. It is not here that you have to do this. Try something else.

QUESTION.QuestionLead: Oops! Sometimes, the XML Web service method GetPrice does not respond, and the user of your application complains that there is no response and no message to inform of the lack of a response.
QUESTION.QuestionText: Where do you have to fix this issue to have a timeout of 10 seconds?

Answer.AnswerWrong: Wrong choice. It is not here that you have to do this. Try something else.

QUESTION.QuestionLead: You want to call a parametrized stored procedure to access the shopping cart in a SQL Server database. You then want to display the shopping cart.
QUESTION.QuestionText: Where do you have to do that?

Answer.AnswerWrong: Wrong choice. It is not here that you have to do this. Try something else.

QUESTION.QuestionLead: Your manager wants you to use a DataGrid to display the checkout data that is coming from the SQL Server database.
QUESTION.QuestionText: Where do you have to implement that?

Answer.AnswerWrong: Wrong choice. It is not here that you have to do this. Try something else.

QUESTION.QuestionLead: You want to place the connection string somewhere else, so that you are able to use it in any page of your application.
QUESTION.QuestionText: Where should you place the connection string?

Answer.AnswerWrong: Wrong choice. It is not here that you have to do this. Try something else.

QUESTION.QuestionLead: Now you have to read this connection string from Web.config (key: SQLconn), before you can fill in your dsCheckout DataSet.
QUESTION.QuestionText: Where do you have to do that?

Answer.AnswerWrong: Wrong choice. It is not here that you have to do this. Try something else.

QUESTION.QuestionLead: You want to validate the username during the login process on the browser (Microsoft Internet Explorer 4.0 or later) and double-check a valid username entry on the server-side.
QUESTION.QuestionText: Where do you have to do this?

Answer.AnswerWrong: Wrong choice. It is not here that you have to do this. Try something else.

QUESTION.QuestionLead: You need to create a reusable class that can access the product information that is in the database.
QUESTION.QuestionText: Where do you create that class?

Answer.AnswerWrong: Wrong choice. It is not here that you have to do this. Try something else.

QUESTION.QuestionLead: You want to use the component (class Products, Method GetProducts) that you just created to display the products in the product page.
QUESTION.QuestionText: Where do you have to do that?

Answer.AnswerWrong: Wrong choice. It is not here that you have to do this. Try something else.

QUESTION.QuestionLead: You want to display a trace output at the end of the product.aspx page, as well as display it with all of the other pages of your ASP.NET Web application. You want to display this information alphabetically, by user-defined category.
QUESTION.QuestionText: Where do you have to do all of that?

AnswerId.ResultValue: You could do that in machine.config, but it is not a good practice. Try something else.
We wanned to trace not only in the product.aspx page, but in all pages. Try something else.

Answer.AnswerWrong: Wrong choice. It is not here that you have to do this. Try something else.

QUESTION.QuestionLead: You have decided that you do not want to have the trace output at the end of the pages; you only want trace output accessible through the trace utility (trace.axd). You want to make sure that you can access the trace utility from a remote computer.
QUESTION.QuestionText: Where do you have to do all of that?

AnswerId.ResultValue: You could do that in machine.config, but it is not a good practice. Try something else.

Answer.AnswerWrong: Wrong choice. It is not here that you have to do this. Try something else.

QUESTION.QuestionLead: You want to have a custom trace in a component.
QUESTION.QuestionText: Where do you have to do that?

Answer.AnswerWrong: Wrong choice. It is not here that you have to do this. Try something else.

QUESTION.QuestionLead: In the product page, you want to include a user control named _menu.ascx that accesses the component to then display a menu.
QUESTION.QuestionText: Where do you have to do that?

Answer.AnswerWrong: Wrong choice. It is not here that you have to do this. Try something else.

QUESTION.QuestionLead: You want to fill a DataSet, located in the products page, with the prospectus XML file named Pros.xml.
QUESTION.QuestionText: Where do you have to do that?

AnswerId.ResultValue: Pros.xml is the prospectus XML file. Try something else.

Answer.AnswerWrong: Wrong choice. It is not here that you have to do this. Try something else.

QUESTION.QuestionLead: You are using a Session variable (named: CartID) to store the ID of the shopping cart. You want to initialize this variable to zero.
QUESTION.QuestionText: Where do you have to do that?

AnswerId.ResultValue: Web.config is used to configure the application, but it is not used to initialize session variables. Try something else.

Answer.AnswerWrong: Wrong choice. It is not here that you have to do this. Try something else.

QUESTION.QuestionLead: Some customer complains that, when they block the cookies, the shopping cart crashes because the session variables are not set correctly.
QUESTION.QuestionText: Where do you have to fix that?

AnswerId.ResultValue: You could fix that in machine.config, but it is not a good practice. Try something else.

Answer.AnswerWrong: Wrong choice. It is not here that you have to do this. Try something else.

Object.TextToDisplay: A non-authenticated user requests the cart.aspx page ...
Microsoft ASP.NET recognizes that the cart.aspx page is secure, but the user is not authenticated ...
Microsoft ASP.NET recognizes that the cart.aspx page is secure, but the user is not authenticated ...
The non-authenticated user is then redirected to the login page.
A non-authenticated user requests the cart.aspx page ...
Microsoft ASP.NET recognizes that the cart.aspx page is secure, but the user is not authenticated ...
Microsoft ASP.NET recognizes that the cart.aspx page is secure, but the user is not authenticated ...
The user is then redirected to the login page ...
The user enters his or her credentials ...
After the user‘s credentials are verified, ASP.NET then redirects the user to the requested cart.aspx page.
After the user‘s credentials are verified, ASP.NET then redirects the user to the requested cart.aspx page.
A user requests the product.aspx page ...
The product.aspx page is sent to the user and ...
The product.aspx page is also stored in the output cache for 90 seconds to ensure better performance if there is another request for the product.aspx page.
Your XML Web service can be used from anywhere by using the Internet.
Your XML Web service can be used from anywhere by using the Internet.
The product.aspx page calls the XML Web service method GetPrice by using the proxy of the XML Web service ...
The proxy of the XML Web service calls the XML Web service method GetPrice through the Internet by using a SOAP message (with the request packed in the SOAP message) ...
The XML Web service gets the SOAP message, unpacks it, extracts the parameter ItemID, and gets the price of the item by using GetPrice XML Web service method ...
The XML Web service then packs the result in a SOAP message ...
The proxy of the XML Web service unpacks the SOAP message that was received by the XML Web service method GetPrice ...
The proxy then gives the returned price to the product.aspx page ...
The product.aspx page then displays the price of the item.
The product.aspx page calls the XML Web service method GetPrice by using the proxy of the XML Web service ...
The proxy of the XML Web service calls the XML Web service method GetPrice through the Internet by using a SOAP message (with the request packed in the SOAP message) ...
The XML Web service is not responding ...
The timeout that is set in the proxy of the XML Web service has reached the end of its waiting time ...
An error is caught in the product.aspx page and a message of non-availability of the XML Web service is then displayed to the user.
The cart.aspx page calls the stored procedure ...
The stored procedure accesses the database ...
The query to the database is performed ...
The stored procedure gets the results of the query ...
The cart.aspx page displays the returned information from the stored procedure.
The checkout.aspx page directly calls the database ...
The query to the database is performed ...
The checkout.aspx page then displays the result of the query in a DataGrid.
Every time you need the connection string in a Web page, you can programmatically access it from any of the pages.
The checkout.aspx page directly calls the database ...
The connection string to the database is retrieved from the Web.config file...
The query to the database is performed ...
The checkout.aspx page then displays the result of the query in a DataGrid.
A user is on the login page and has entered his or her credentials ...
The validation (RequierdFieldValidator on the input control txtUserName) is first performed on the client-side (if the browser is Internet Explorer 4.0 or later) ...
If the credentials are recognized as valid on the client-side, then Microsoft ASP.NET performs a double-check on the server-side to avoid spoofing.
A component is compiled and it can then be reused from any Web pages ...
For example, the products.aspx page could use this component to get the list of products from the database.
The products.aspx page is about to display a list of products ...
A component is called to get a DataSet with all of the products listed ...
The products.aspx page binds the DataSet to a DataGrid to display the products list to the user.
Now, the Web.config file is set up to trace in all of the pages of your ASP.NET Web application and then display the information at the end of the pages (alphabetically ordered).
With your new trace settings, the Web.config file is now set up to trace in all of the pages of your ASP.NET Web application, but it will not display the information at the end of the pages ...
The trace information is accessible through the trace utility (trace.axd). You can also access the trace utility from a remote computer.
Now, you can trace into the component and then display the trace directly in the calling page (or through the trace utility) ...
For instance, if checkout.aspx page calls the component, your custom trace that was done in your component will be added to the trace information on the checkout.aspx page.
Now, the user control named _menu.ascx is included in the product.aspx page.
Now, the user control named _menu.ascx is included in the product.aspx page.
Now, the user control named _menu.ascx is included in the product.aspx page.
The product.aspx page fills its DataSet dsProspectus ...
by reading the file Pros.xml ...
And then the product.aspx page binds the DataSet in a DataGrid.
When a new session starts, the Session_Start event in the global.asax file is fired and the session variable CartID is initialized to zero ...
Then, you can programmatically assign a real cart ID when the user uses the shopping cart for the first time, or when the user logs on to enter their credentials in your ASP.NET Web application.
When a user blocks the cookies in the browser (or uses an older browser that does not supports cookies), the session variables can still be used because now the session ID is sent through the URL ...
instead of being sent by using a cookie.
